We are back bois

This fear of death is something that we all have.  We can't avoid it no matter how hard we try.  But would you truly want to live forever? At first thought, you may say "yes, of course!" but think about it: you will lose everyone you love as you live for eternity.  You won't be able to take yourself out of it, because you can't die.  Death is fundamental to every living thing's experience, but what makes it worse for us is that we humans can understand that death is coming.  Everyone of us lives this life: we are thrust into a painful existence, accomplish unimportant tasks, and die, all the while fearing our inevitable outcome.  This is the story of everyone, the specifics of life hardly matter.  Now go watch Synecdoche, New York (2008) by Charlie Kaufman, you have nothing better to do.

If you're reading this... you are going to die. But that would be the case even if you didn't. It could happen at any time, at any place, to anyone.  This is something we often forget.  And if we do remember it, we may dismiss it, saying that death doesn't concern us, or it isn't scary.  But there is nothing scarier than knowing for a fact that you are soon to die.  Plato said that philosophy prepares one for death, but that simply isn't true.  You can go your whole life not fearing death but nothing will compare to the terror you feel moments, hours, even days before dying.  Each way of dying is terrible.  There isn't one "best way".  Whether you die by Alzheimer's, forgetting everyone and everything you know, as you lose all semblance of self, or rotting away in a hospital bed from some terrible cancer.  Just imagine the gut-wrenching terror that you would feel as you are in a hospital surrounded by loved ones, knowing that you could pass at any moment.
